If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified:
People, not nature, teach girls that they are better at subjects like art and literature, and boys are better at maths and science. Also, young people don't often see women working in science jobs. In cartoons and stories, scientists, inventors, and astronauts are usually men.

Also, some people think scientists are strange, not very social, or work alone. This is not true, but it’s what the media often shows. Because of this, girls might not think science is a good job for them, and they might not feel they fit in. 

If girls saw more women working as scientists, they would feel more confident and like they belong in science and maths.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. simplified:
The Scallion is a newspaper that comes out every week. It’s given away for free in buildings for teachers and students. About 10,000 students read it. Students write and make the newspaper themselves.

A survey (a kind of question paper) shows students and teachers like the newspaper a lot. They enjoy reading it for fun, to learn about different cultures, and to get experience for jobs. 

Printing the newspaper costs a lot of money. Also, not all students can easily get a copy because they have to go to university to pick one up. Another problem is that many newspapers are thrown away on the university grounds as rubbish, which is bad for the environment.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified:
At Girox Foods, about 12 out of 100 workers leave their jobs each year. This might not sound like a lot, but most companies in this business only lose 7 out of 100 workers. This report is to find out why our workers are leaving. We want to understand what makes our workers happy at work. Then, we will suggest ways to make things better so more workers will stay with us. 

**Employee turnover** means the number of workers who leave a company each year.
**Employee engagement** means how happy and interested workers are in their jobs.
**Employee retention** means keeping workers at the company.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified: What the speaker said felt very true. I really think that when we are always in touch with people, we can also feel lonely. I don’t think this is a big problem for people my age, because we grew up without always having phones and the internet. We know how to be by ourselves, and we know that’s okay. But younger people, under 20, are different. They are always talking to people, so they don’t often feel alone. They might not learn how to enjoy being with themselves. Also, they are learning to talk by sending messages. You can change these messages before you send them. This is different from talking to someone face to face, where you have to think quickly and say what you mean right away.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: Don’t always say something good and then something bad. If you always give good and bad feedback together, the good things might not seem important. Make sure you sometimes say something good without also saying what could be better. Try not to always give advice for improvement.
